clinical_study.brief_title: Understanding Circadian Responses to Light in Persons With Mild Cognitive Impairment
clinical_study.official_title: Understanding Circadian Responses to Light in Persons With Mild Cognitive Impairment and Alzheimer's Disease

lead_sponsor.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

clinical_study.source: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to investigate the relationship between light, the thickness of the pigment at the back of your eye, melatonin levels, and memory. The study will investigate whether changing light distribution pattern from "on-axis"' (i.e., directed along the eye's visual axis to the fovea) to "off-axis" (i.e., directed on the periphery of the eye's visual axis) impact melatonin suppression in 24 mild cognitive impairment participants and 24 healthy, age-matched controls.

detailed_description.textblock: Eligible enrolled subjects will be exposed to 4 different lighting conditions in addition to one dark control condition. There will be 5 study session and each one will last for 90 minutes and will be separated by one week. Subjects will collect 3 saliva samples, each one 30 minutes apart for melatonin levels during each study session.

primary_outcome.time_frame: one sample will be collected every 30 minutes during each 90 minute study session up to 5 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Saliva samples will be collected for melatonin analysis

arm_group.description: Blue light (λmax = 451 nm) on and off axis
Green light (λmax = 522 nm) on and off axis

intervention.description: Custom made lighting fixture that will deliver the blue lighting intervention
Custom made lighting fixture that will deliver the green lighting intervention

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- mild cognitive impairment
- age matched healthy control
- macular pigment density either < 0.3 or > 0.5
Exclusion Criteria:
- extensive brain vascular disease
- Parkinson's disease
- bipolar disorder
- seasonal depression
- diabetes
- high blood pressure
- obstructing cataracts
- macular degeneration
- diabetic retinopathy
- use of melatonin supplements
- use of beta blockers
- use of sleep medications
- use of antidepressant medication
